hints_html:
Recall the notation and terminology. A convergent is given by

\(\displaystyle [a_{0};a_{1},a_{2},...,a_{n}] = \frac{h_{n}}{k_{n}}\)

where we also have the recurrence relations

\[\begin{aligned} h_{n} &= a_{n}h_{n-1} + h_{n-2}\\ k_{n} &= a_{n}k_{n-1} + k_{n-2}\end{aligned}\]

subject to the initial conditions \(\displaystyle h_{-1} = 1, h_{-2} = 0, k_{-1} = 0, k_{-2} = 1\).
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
A convergent is given by

\(\displaystyle [a_{0};a_{1},a_{2},...,a_{n}] = \frac{h_{n}}{k_{n}}\)

where we also have the recurrence relations

\[\begin{aligned} h_{n} &= a_{n}h_{n-1} + h_{n-2}\\ k_{n} &= a_{n}k_{n-1} + k_{n-2}\end{aligned}\]

subject to the initial conditions \(\displaystyle h_{-1} = 1, h_{-2} = 0, k_{-1} = 0, k_{-2} = 1\).

Plugging in our values, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} h_{0} &= a_{0}h_{0-1} + h_{0-2} = (0)(1) + 0 = 0\\ k_{0} &= a_{0}k_{0-1} + k_{0-2} = (0)(0) + 1 = 1\\ h_{1} &= a_{1}h_{1-1} + h_{1-2} = (1)(0) + 1 = 1\\ k_{1} &= a_{1}k_{1-1} + k_{1-2} = (1)(1) + 0 = 1\\ h_{2} &= a_{2}h_{2-1} + h_{2-2} = (2)(1) + 0 = 2\\ k_{2} &= a_{2}k_{2-1} + k_{2-2} = (2)(1) + 1 = 3\\ h_{3} &= a_{3}h_{3-1} + h_{3-2} = (3)(2) + 1 = 7\\ k_{3} &= a_{3}k_{3-1} + k_{3-2} = (3)(3) + 1 = 10\\ h_{4} &= a_{4}h_{4-1} + h_{4-2} = (4)(7) + 2 = 30\\ k_{4} &= a_{4}k_{4-1} + k_{4-2} = (4)(10) + 3 = 43\end{aligned}\]

Thus the convergents are

\(\displaystyle \left\{0,1,\frac{2}{3},\frac{7}{10},\frac{30}{43} \right\}\)
sols_raw:
A convergent is given by

<math> \displaystyle [a_{0};a_{1},a_{2},...,a_{n}] = \frac{h_{n}}{k_{n}}</math>

where we also have the recurrence relations

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
h_{n} &= a_{n}h_{n-1} + h_{n-2}\\
k_{n} &= a_{n}k_{n-1} + k_{n-2}
\end{align}
</math>

subject to the initial conditions <math> \displaystyle h_{-1} = 1, h_{-2} = 0, k_{-1} = 0, k_{-2} = 1</math>.

Plugging in our values, we see that 

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
h_{0} &= a_{0}h_{0-1} + h_{0-2} = (0)(1) + 0 = 0\\
k_{0} &= a_{0}k_{0-1} + k_{0-2} = (0)(0) + 1 = 1\\
h_{1} &= a_{1}h_{1-1} + h_{1-2} = (1)(0) + 1 = 1\\
k_{1} &= a_{1}k_{1-1} + k_{1-2} = (1)(1) + 0 = 1\\
h_{2} &= a_{2}h_{2-1} + h_{2-2} = (2)(1) + 0 = 2\\
k_{2} &= a_{2}k_{2-1} + k_{2-2} = (2)(1) + 1 = 3\\
h_{3} &= a_{3}h_{3-1} + h_{3-2} = (3)(2) + 1 = 7\\
k_{3} &= a_{3}k_{3-1} + k_{3-2} = (3)(3) + 1 = 10\\
h_{4} &= a_{4}h_{4-1} + h_{4-2} = (4)(7) + 2 = 30\\
k_{4} &= a_{4}k_{4-1} + k_{4-2} = (4)(10) + 3 = 43
\end{align}
</math>

Thus the convergents are

<math> \displaystyle \left\{0,1,\frac{2}{3},\frac{7}{10},\frac{30}{43} \right\}</math>
statement_html: Compute the convergents of the continued fraction \(\displaystyle [0;1,2,3,4]\).
statement_latex:
Compute the convergents of the continued fraction
$\displaystyle [0;1,2,3,4]$.
statement_raw: Compute the convergents of the continued fraction <math> \displaystyle [0;1,2,3,4]</math>.
